questions.question: Which Question Paper Type of Chemistry is given to you?
questions.explanation: The header on the page states "PAPER TYPE: E".

questions.question: A mixture is different from a compound because

options.text: the properties of a compound are those of its individual constituents while those of a mixture differ from its constituents
a mixture is always homogeneous while a compound is not
the constituent of a compound are chemically bound together while those of a mixture are not
a mixture can be represented by a chemical formula while a compound cannot

questions.explanation: In compounds, elements are chemically bonded in fixed ratios; in mixtures, components are not chemically bonded and can be separated by physical methods.

questions.question: What is the percentage of sulphur in sulphur (IV) oxide?
questions.explanation: For \(\text{SO}_2\): molar mass \(= 32 + 2(16) = 64\). Percentage of S \(= \frac{32}{64}\times 100 = 50\%\). This computed value corresponds to option D, not A; using standard atomic masses, the correct percentage is 50%.

questions.question: A gas X diffuses twice as fast as gas Y. If the relative molecular mass of X is 32, calculate the relative molecular mass of Y.
questions.explanation: Graham’s law: \(\frac{r_X}{r_Y} = \sqrt{\frac{M_Y}{M_X}}\). Given \(r_X = 2r_Y\): \(2 = \sqrt{\frac{M_Y}{32}}\). Squaring: \(4 = \frac{M_Y}{32}\Rightarrow M_Y = 128\).

questions.question: 200 cm\(^3\) of a gas at 25\(^\circ\)C exerts a pressure of 700 mmHg. Calculate its pressure if its volume increases 350 cm\(^3\) at 75\(^\circ\)C.
An element X has electron configuration \(1s^2\,2s^2\,2p^6\,3s^2\,3p^5\). Which of the following statements is correct about the element?

options.text: It has a completely filled p-orbital
It has 5 electrons in its outermost shell.
It belongs to group II on the periodic table

questions.explanation: The outer configuration is \(3s^2 3p^5\) (7 valence electrons), characteristic of Group 17 (halogens).

questions.question: Beryllium and aluminium have similar properties because they

options.text: are positioned diagonally to each other

questions.explanation: Be and Al show diagonal relationship in the periodic table, giving similar chemical properties.

questions.question: If the difference in electronegativity of elements P and Q is 3.0. The bond that will be formed between them is
questions.explanation: A large electronegativity difference (about 1.7 or greater) indicates electron transfer, hence ionic bonding.

questions.question: How many protons, neutrons and electrons respectively are present in the element \(^{60}_{27}\text{Co}\)?
questions.explanation: Atomic number 27 gives 27 protons. Neutrons = 60 − 27 = 33. For a neutral atom, electrons = protons = 27.

questions.question: The radioactive radiation used in studying the arrangement of particles in giant organic molecules is
questions.explanation: X-ray diffraction is used to study structures/arrangements in large molecules and crystalline materials.

questions.question: A silicon-containing ore has 92% \(^{28}\text{Si}\), 5% \(^{29}\text{Si}\) and 3% \(^{30}\text{Si}\). Calculate the relative atomic mass of the silicon.
The nitrogen obtained from air has a density higher than the one from nitrogen-containing compounds because the one from air is contaminated with
questions.explanation: Nitrogen from air contains traces of heavier noble gases (especially argon), increasing its density.

questions.question: Water is said to be temporarily hard when it contains
questions.explanation: Temporary hardness is due to calcium and magnesium hydrogencarbonates, removable by boiling.

questions.question: On exposure to the atmosphere, a hydrated salt loses its water of crystallization to become anhydrous. This phenomenon is referred to as
questions.explanation: Efflorescence is the loss of water of crystallization by hydrated salts on exposure to air.

questions.question: 16.55 g of lead (II) trioxonitrate (V) was dissolved in 100 g of distilled water at 20°C, calculate the solubility of the solute in mol dm\(^{-3}\). [Pb = 207, N = 14, O = 16]
questions.explanation: The prompt asks for solubility in \(\text{mol dm}^{-3}\), but the options shown in the image are in grams (g). From the data: molar mass of \(\text{Pb(NO}_3)_2\) is \(207 + 2(14 + 3\times 16) = 207 + 2(62) = 331\,\text{g mol}^{-1}\). Moles in 16.55 g: \(\frac{16.55}{331} = 0.050\,\text{mol}\). 100 g water \(\approx 0.100\,\text{dm}^3\). Concentration \(= \frac{0.050}{0.100} = 0.50\,\text{mol dm}^{-3}\). The matching numerical option shown is "0.50 g" (D), but its unit conflicts with the question as printed.

questions.question: The dispersion of a liquid in a liquid medium will give
questions.explanation: A liquid dispersed in another liquid forms an emulsion (e.g., milk).

questions.question: The major and most effective way of controlling pollution is to

options.text: improve machinery so that the substances released from combustion are less harmful
pass strict laws against it by individuals and companies
educate people on the causes and effects of pollution
convert chemical wastes to harmless substances before releasing them into the environment

questions.explanation: Preventing pollution at source by treating wastes to harmless products before discharge is the most direct and effective control method among the options.

questions.question: The basicity of \(\text{CH}_3\text{COOH}\) is
questions.explanation: Basicity is the number of replaceable (ionizable) hydrogen ions per molecule of acid. Ethanoic acid has one ionizable H in the -COOH group.

questions.question: The colour of litmus in a neutral medium is
questions.explanation: Litmus is purple at neutral pH (about 7).

questions.question: The mathematical expression of pH is
questions.explanation: By definition, \(\text{pH} = -\log_{10}[\text{H}^+]\), equivalently \(\log_{10}\!\left(\frac{1}{[\text{H}^+]}\right)\). The option using \([\text{H}_3\text{O}^+]\) matches this.

questions.question: Which of the following salts will turn blue litmus red?
questions.explanation: A salt that turns blue litmus red is acidic. Potassium hydrogen tetraoxosulphate is an acid salt (contains replaceable H), giving an acidic solution.

questions.question: \(\text{Zn}_{(s)} + \text{CuSO}_{4(aq)} \rightarrow \text{ZnSO}_{4(aq)} + \text{Cu}_{(s)}\). In the reaction above, the oxidation number of the reducing agent changes from
questions.explanation: The reducing agent is Zn. Zn goes from 0 in Zn(s) to +2 in ZnSO4.

questions.question: \(\text{H}_2\text{O}_{(g)} + \text{C}_{(s)} \rightarrow \text{H}_{2(g)} + \text{CO}_{(g)}\). The oxidizing agent in the reaction above is
questions.explanation: Oxidizing agent is reduced. Hydrogen in H2O goes from +1 to 0 in H2 (reduction), so H2O is the oxidizing agent.

questions.question: Calculate the quantity of electricity in coulombs required to liberate 10 g of copper from a copper compound. [Cu = 64, \(F = 96500\,\text{C mol}^{-1}\)]
questions.explanation: Moles of Cu: \(n = \frac{10}{64} = 0.15625\,\text{mol}\). For \(\text{Cu}^{2+} + 2e^- \rightarrow \text{Cu}\), charge \(Q = 2nF = 2(0.15625)(96500) = 30156.25\,\text{C}\). This matches option B (30156.3), not C; using the given data, the correct option is B.

questions.question: How many faraday of electricity is required to produce 0.25 mole of copper?
questions.explanation: Copper is deposited from \(\text{Cu}^{2+}\): 1 mol Cu needs 2 mol electrons = 2F. For 0.25 mol Cu, faradays needed \(= 0.25\times 2 = 0.50F\). That corresponds to option D, not A.

questions.question: Z in diagram below represents...
questions.explanation: In the energy profile, Z is shown as the vertical difference between the energy level of reactants (A+B) and products (C+D). That vertical change corresponds to the enthalpy change (heat of reaction, \(\Delta H\)).

questions.question: If the change in free energy of a system is -899 J mol\(^{-1}\) and the entropy change is 10 J mol\(^{-1}\) K\(^{-1}\) at 25°C, calculate the enthalpy change.
questions.explanation: Use \(\Delta G = \Delta H - T\Delta S\). \(T = 25 + 273 = 298\,\text{K}\). So \(\Delta H = \Delta G + T\Delta S = -899 + 298\times 10 = -899 + 2980 = 2081\,\text{J mol}^{-1}\). This matches option A, not D.

questions.question: In an equilibrium reaction, which of the following conditions indicates that maximum yield of the product will be obtained?

options.text: Equilibrium constant is less than zero

questions.explanation: A very large equilibrium constant means equilibrium lies far to the product side, giving maximum yield of products.

questions.question: In a chemical reaction, the change in concentration of a reactant with time is
questions.explanation: Rate of reaction is defined as change in concentration per unit time.

questions.question: \(\text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-}(aq) + \text{H}_2\text{O}_{(l)} \rightleftharpoons 2\text{CrO}_4^{2-}(aq) + 2\text{H}^+_{(aq)}\). What happens to the reaction above when the hydrogen ion concentration is increased?

options.text: more of the products will be formed
the equilibrium position will shift to the right
the equilibrium position will shift to the left.

questions.explanation: Increasing \([\text{H}^+]\) adds a product; by Le Châtelier’s principle the equilibrium shifts left to consume excess \(\text{H}^+\), forming more dichromate.

questions.question: Which of the following will liberate hydrogen from dilute tetraoxosulphate (VI) acid?
questions.explanation: Metals above hydrogen in the reactivity series displace hydrogen from dilute acids. Magnesium is above hydrogen; copper and gold are below, and lead is often protected by insoluble PbSO4.

questions.question: In the diagram, the function of the concentrated \(\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4\) is to
questions.explanation: Concentrated \(\text{H}_2\text{SO}_4\) is a strong dehydrating agent used to remove water vapour, thus drying the gas.

questions.question: The gas that is removed by the water in the flask is
questions.explanation: In chlorine preparation, hydrogen chloride is a common impurity. Passing the gas through water removes HCl because it is very soluble, while chlorine is less soluble.

questions.question: Fluorine does not occur in the free state in nature because

options.text: it belongs to the halogen family

questions.explanation: Fluorine is extremely reactive and quickly forms compounds (fluorides), so it is not found free in nature.

questions.question: In the extraction of sodium from fused sodium chloride, the anode is made of platinum because

options.text: sodium is formed at the anode
chlorine is formed at the anode
sodium does not react with platinum
chlorine does not react with platinum

questions.explanation: Chlorine is liberated at the anode and platinum is used because it is resistant to attack by chlorine.

questions.question: A compound that gives a brick-red colour to a non-luminous flame is likely to contain
questions.explanation: Calcium ions give a brick-red (orange-red) flame in flame tests.

questions.question: In the electrolytic extraction of calcium from calcium chloride, the cathode is
questions.explanation: In the electrolysis of molten CaCl2, calcium metal is deposited at the cathode; iron/steel is commonly used as the cathode material in such setups (graphite is typically an anode).

questions.question: A few drops of NaOH solution was added to an unknown salt forming a white precipitate which is insoluble in excess solution. The cation likely present is
questions.explanation: Pb(OH)2 forms a white precipitate that is insoluble in excess NaOH under typical qualitative analysis conditions. (Zn(OH)2 and Al(OH)3 dissolve in excess NaOH.)

questions.question: The general formula of haloalkanes where X represents the halide is
questions.explanation: Haloalkanes are derived from alkanes (\(\text{C}_n\text{H}_{2n+2}\)) by replacing one H with X, giving \(\text{C}_n\text{H}_{2n+1}\text{X}\).

questions.question: The IUPAC nomenclature of the compound above is
questions.explanation: The parent chain is butanol with the -OH given the lowest possible number (butan-1-ol). Numbering from the OH end gives Cl at C2 and Br at C3. Substituents are listed alphabetically: bromo before chloro, giving 3-bromo-2-chlorobutanol.

questions.question: The alkanol obtained from the production of soap is
questions.explanation: Soap production (saponification of fats/oils) produces glycerol as the alcohol by-product.

questions.question: Ethyne is passed through a hot tube containing organo-nickel catalyst to produce
questions.explanation: Under suitable catalytic conditions, ethyne (acetylene) can trimerize to form benzene: \(3\text{C}_2\text{H}_2 \rightarrow \text{C}_6\text{H}_6\).

questions.question: Due to the unstable nature of ethyne, it is stored by dissolving in
questions.explanation: Ethyne is stored dissolved in acetone (propanone) in cylinders to reduce explosion risk.

questions.question: The process of converting starch to ethanol is
questions.explanation: Starch is first broken to sugars and then yeast fermentation converts sugars to ethanol and CO2.

questions.question: The polymer used in making car rear lights is
questions.explanation: Perspex (PMMA) is a transparent, tough plastic used for lenses and light covers such as car rear lights.

questions.question: \(\text{CH}_3\text{COOC}_2\text{H}_5{}_{(l)} + \text{H}_2\text{O}_{(l)} \rightleftharpoons \text{CH}_3\text{COOH}_{(aq)} + \text{C}_2\text{H}_5\text{OH}_{(aq)}\). The purpose of \(\text{H}^+\) in the reaction above is to

options.text: maintain the solution at a constant pH
increase the rate of the hydrolysis
decrease the rate of the reverse reaction

questions.explanation: Acid (H+) catalyzes ester hydrolysis by lowering activation energy, increasing reaction rate without changing equilibrium position.

questions.question: A hydrocarbon has an empirical formula CH and a vapour density of 39. Determine its molecular formula. [C = 12, H = 1]
questions.explanation: Vapour density 39 implies molar mass \(M = 2\times 39 = 78\). Empirical mass of CH is \(12+1 = 13\). Multiplier \(= \frac{78}{13} = 6\). Molecular formula \(= (\text{CH})_6 = \text{C}_6\text{H}_6\).

questions.question: Polystyrene is widely used as packaging materials for fragile objects during transportation because of its
questions.explanation: Expanded polystyrene foam cushions shocks because it is easily compressed, absorbing impact energy to protect fragile objects.

questions.question: The process of converting linear alkanes to branched chain and cyclic hydrocarbons by heating in the presence of a catalyst to improve the quality of petrol is referred to as
questions.explanation: Catalytic reforming converts straight-chain hydrocarbons into branched/cyclic/aromatic hydrocarbons, increasing octane number.

questions.question: The petroleum fraction that is used in heating furnaces in industries is
questions.explanation: Diesel (gas oil) is commonly used as fuel for industrial heating and furnaces compared with gasoline (motor fuel) and lubricating oil (non-fuel use).
